sn4.6:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn4.6:1.3: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.
sn4.6:2.1: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, manifested in the form of a huge serpent king and approached him.
sn4.6:2.2: Its body was like a huge canoe carved from a single tree.
sn4.6:2.4: Its hood was like a large brewer’s sieve.
sn4.6:2.6: Its eyes were like those big bronze dishes from Kosala.
sn4.6:2.8: Its tongue flickered from its mouth like lightning flashes in a thunderstorm.
sn4.6:2.10: The sound of its breathing was like the puffing of a blacksmith’s bellows.
sn4.6:3.1: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn4.6:4.3: It’s appropriate for such a person
sn4.6:5.1: Though there are lots of creepy crawlies,
sn4.6:5.2: and lots of flies and snakes,
sn4.6:5.4: of a great sage in that empty hut.
sn4.6:6.1: Though the sky may split and the earth may quake,
sn4.6:6.2: and all creatures be stricken with fear;
sn4.6:6.3: and even if an arrow’s aimed at their breast,
sn4.6:6.4: the Buddhas take no shelter in attachments.”
sn4.6:7.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
